articles.headline: Sinema’s Blockade on Tax Rates Prods Democrats Toward Billionaires’ Tax
articles.snippet: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s refusal to raise rates on high earners and major corporations has led Democrats to consider proposals once championed only by the party’s most liberal flank.
articles.abstract: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s refusal to raise rates on high earners and major corporations has led Democrats to consider proposals once championed only by the party’s most liberal flank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona and one of her party’s only holdouts on President Biden’s sprawling budget bill, has cultivated a profile in Congress as a business-minded centrist.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Again Refuses to Block Texas Abortion Law
articles.snippet: But the court said it would hear arguments on Nov. 1 on challenges to the law from the Biden administration and abortion providers in the state.
articles.abstract: But the court said it would hear arguments on Nov. 1 on challenges to the law from the Biden administration and abortion providers in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday once again refused to immediately block a Texas law that bans most abortions after six weeks. But in an unusual move, the justices agreed to fast-track their consideration of appeals from the Justice Department and abortion providers in Texas, scheduling arguments for Nov. 1.

articles.headline: Eating Disorders and Social Media Prove Difficult to Untangle
articles.snippet: Social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram try to monitor for content related to the problem, but it is not always clear what to do about it.
articles.abstract: Social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram try to monitor for content related to the problem, but it is not always clear what to do about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 27-year-old YouTube star, prodded by her millions of followers with concerns about her health. A 19-year-old TikTok creator who features posts about being skinny. Teen communities throughout the internet, cleverly naming and culling their discussions to avoid detection.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Kellen Browning and Erin Woo

articles.headline: Internal Alarm, Public Shrugs: Facebook’s Employees Dissect Its Election Role
articles.snippet: Company documents show that the social network’s employees repeatedly raised red flags about the spread of misinformation and conspiracies before and after the contested November vote.
articles.abstract: Company documents show that the social network’s employees repeatedly raised red flags about the spread of misinformation and conspiracies before and after the contested November vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sixteen months before last November’s presidential election, a researcher at Facebook described an alarming development. She was getting content about the conspiracy theory QAnon within a week of opening an experimental account, she wrote in an internal report.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: The Sheikh, the Businessman and a Hacking Mystery on 3 Continents
articles.snippet: A case that began with a feud in the United Arab Emirates, stretched from the U.S. to India and is now playing out in the British courts offers a rare glimpse into the anatomy of a hack-and-leak operation.
articles.abstract: A case that began with a feud in the United Arab Emirates, stretched from the U.S. to India and is now playing out in the British courts offers a rare glimpse into the anatomy of a hack-and-leak operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Farhad Azima navigated the shadowlands where business blends with intrigue and the limits of the law. He popped up in the Iran-contra affair, was named in a Clinton-era fund-raising scandal and owned airlines that flew weapons into war zones.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Karan Deep Singh

articles.headline: Biden the Dealmaker Finds That Compromise Can Have Consequences
articles.snippet: The president pushed for an expansive agenda knowing that he would most likely have to pare it back, leaving a sense of disappointment that could hurt his party at the polls.
articles.abstract: The president pushed for an expansive agenda knowing that he would most likely have to pare it back, leaving a sense of disappointment that could hurt his party at the polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of negotiations on President Biden’s infrastructure and spending bill.]

articles.headline: She Is Breaking Glass Ceilings in Space, but Facing Sexism on Earth
articles.snippet: Sanitary pads and makeup: A Chinese astronaut’s six-month stay aboard the country’s space station has revealed conflicted cultural values toward gender.
articles.abstract: Sanitary pads and makeup: A Chinese astronaut’s six-month stay aboard the country’s space station has revealed conflicted cultural values toward gender.
articles.lead_paragraph: Col. Wang Yaping is a pilot in the People’s Liberation Army’s Air Force. She is a space veteran, now making her second trip into orbit. She is set in the coming weeks to be the first Chinese woman to walk in space as China’s space station glides around Earth at 17,100 miles per hour.

articles.headline: U.S. Struggles With Afghan Evacuees Weeded Out, and Now in Limbo
articles.snippet: No final decisions have been made, but dozens red-flagged for apparent criminal pasts or links to militants have been sent to a base in Kosovo, where their fate is uncertain.
articles.abstract: No final decisions have been made, but dozens red-flagged for apparent criminal pasts or links to militants have been sent to a base in Kosovo, where their fate is uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months after the evacuation of 80,000 Afghans fleeing the Taliban takeover, most have cleared subsequent vetting for admission into the United States. Some initially raised possible security issues — like evacuees who shared a name with terrorism suspects — but were absolved on closer scrutiny.

articles.headline: In India, Facebook Grapples With an Amplified Version of Its Problems
articles.snippet: Internal documents show a struggle with misinformation, hate speech and celebrations of violence in the country, the company’s biggest market.
articles.abstract: Internal documents show a struggle with misinformation, hate speech and celebrations of violence in the country, the company’s biggest market.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 4, 2019, a Facebook researcher created a new user account to see what it was like to experience the social media site as a person living in Kerala, India.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba

articles.headline: A Rare Win in the Cat-and-Mouse Game of Ransomware
articles.snippet: A team of private security sleuths, in their first public detailing of their efforts, discuss how they used cybercriminals’ mistakes to quietly help victims recover their data.
articles.abstract: A team of private security sleuths, in their first public detailing of their efforts, discuss how they used cybercriminals’ mistakes to quietly help victims recover their data.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a year rife with ransomware attacks, when cybercriminals have held the data of police departments, grocery and pharmacy chains, hospitals, pipelines and water treatment plants hostage with computer code, it was a win, rare in the scale of its success.

articles.headline: Where Facts Were No Match for Fear
articles.snippet: Civic boosters in central Montana hoped for some federal money to promote tourism. A disinformation campaign got in the way.
articles.abstract: Civic boosters in central Montana hoped for some federal money to promote tourism. A disinformation campaign got in the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Mont. — In the summer of 2020, as pandemic shutdowns closed businesses and racial justice protests erupted on American streets, Rae Grulkowski, a 56-year-old businesswoman who had never been involved in politics but was alarmed about what was happening to the country, found a way to make a difference.

articles.headline: A C.I.A. Fighter, a Somali Bomb Maker, and a Faltering Shadow War
articles.snippet: The hunt for an elusive Somali militant illustrates why Al Shabab, despite a decade of American covert action, are at their strongest in years.
articles.abstract: The hunt for an elusive Somali militant illustrates why Al Shabab, despite a decade of American covert action, are at their strongest in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The C.I.A. convoy rolled out of Mogadishu in the dead of night, headed south along a crumbling ocean road that led deep into territory controlled by Al Shabab, one of Africa’s deadliest militant groups.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Inside Amazon’s Worst Human Resources Problem
articles.snippet: A knot of problems with Amazon’s system for handling paid and unpaid leaves has led to devastating consequences for workers.
articles.abstract: A knot of problems with Amazon’s system for handling paid and unpaid leaves has led to devastating consequences for workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Tara Jones, an Amazon warehouse worker in Oklahoma, cradled her newborn, glanced over her pay stub on her phone and noticed that she had been underpaid by a significant chunk: $90 out of $540.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor, Karen Weise and Grace Ashford

articles.headline: Inside the Big Facebook Leak
articles.snippet: In a time of mega-leaks, journalists’ sources have become power players. Frances Haugen, the former Facebook product manager who shared company documents, led a meticulous media rollout.
articles.abstract: In a time of mega-leaks, journalists’ sources have become power players. Frances Haugen, the former Facebook product manager who shared company documents, led a meticulous media rollout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frances Haugen first met Jeff Horwitz, a tech-industry reporter for The Wall Street Journal, early last December on a hiking trail near the Chabot Space & Science Center in Oakland, Calif.

articles.headline: Ignoring Sanctions, Russia Renews Broad Cybersurveillance Operation
articles.snippet: The new campaign came only months after President Biden imposed sanctions on Moscow in response to a series of spy operations it had conducted around the world.
articles.abstract: The new campaign came only months after President Biden imposed sanctions on Moscow in response to a series of spy operations it had conducted around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEA ISLAND, Ga. — Russia’s premier intelligence agency has launched another campaign to pierce thousands of U.S. government, corporate and think-tank computer networks, Microsoft officials and cybersecurity experts warned on Sunday, only months after President Biden imposed sanctions on Moscow in response to a series of sophisticated spy operations it had conducted around the world.

articles.headline: Why Amazon Is in Business With Judge Judy
articles.snippet: The company hopes a new court show starring the straight-talking judge will help turbocharge its free, ad-supported streaming platform, IMDb TV.
articles.abstract: The company hopes a new court show starring the straight-talking judge will help turbocharge its free, ad-supported streaming platform, IMDb TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — And you thought Amazon’s ambitions in Hollywood were limited to a single streaming service.

articles.headline: I’m Not a Pilot, but I Just Flew a Helicopter Over California
articles.snippet: New technology, a few iPads and a quick tutorial can help anyone act like a pilot. Dealing with air traffic control is another matter.
articles.abstract: New technology, a few iPads and a quick tutorial can help anyone act like a pilot. Dealing with air traffic control is another matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMARILLO, Calif. — On a recent Wednesday afternoon, I flew a helicopter over Ventura County, just north of Los Angeles.

articles.headline: A 100-Year-Old Priest Was Nudged From His Parish. He Has No Plan to Retire.
articles.snippet: The Rev. Luis Urriza arrived in Beaumont, Texas, nearly 70 years ago and founded the thriving Cristo Rey parish. His religious order has now called him back to Spain.
articles.abstract: The Rev. Luis Urriza arrived in Beaumont, Texas, nearly 70 years ago and founded the thriving Cristo Rey parish. His religious order has now called him back to Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEAUMONT, Texas — The priest needed a hand while tugging on layer after layer of vestments. He carried a magnifying glass to help him read a handwritten list of prayer intentions. But as he jingled a bell to let the congregation know that Mass was beginning, he abandoned his walker and cane, singing along with the choir as he ambled up the center aisle toward the altar.

articles.headline: Whose Promised Land? A Journey Into a Divided Israel
articles.snippet: Two Times journalists drive the length of Israel to discover what it means to be Israeli today. They meet a kaleidoscope of people, searching for belonging but far apart on how to find it.
articles.abstract: Two Times journalists drive the length of Israel to discover what it means to be Israeli today. They meet a kaleidoscope of people, searching for belonging but far apart on how to find it.
articles.lead_paragraph: We found Shai Melamud just before dusk, standing on his patio near Israel’s northern border, opposite a slope scorched black by recent rocket fire from Lebanon.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: Facebook Whistle-Blower Brings Campaign to Europe After Disclosures
articles.snippet: Beginning a European tour in Britain, the former Facebook manager was questioned by policymakers drafting tougher tech regulations.
articles.abstract: Beginning a European tour in Britain, the former Facebook manager was questioned by policymakers drafting tougher tech regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook has lurched from controversy to controversy since Mark Zuckerberg started it as a Harvard undergrad in 2004. But the actions of Frances Haugen, a former product manager, have created a backlash and public relations crisis that stand apart.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Facebook Wrestles With the Features It Used to Define Social Networking
articles.snippet: Likes and shares made the social media site what it is. Now, company documents show, it’s struggling to deal with their effects.
articles.abstract: Likes and shares made the social media site what it is. Now, company documents show, it’s struggling to deal with their effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2019, Facebook researchers began a new study of one of the social network’s foundational features: the Like button.

articles.headline: Tesla Value Tops $1 Trillion After Hertz Orders 100,000 Cars
articles.snippet: The order, to be fulfilled between now and the end of next year, is a sign of the growing momentum in the shift toward electric cars.
articles.abstract: The order, to be fulfilled between now and the end of next year, is a sign of the growing momentum in the shift toward electric cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hertz said on Monday that it would convert more than 20 percent of its rental fleet to Tesla’s electric cars by the end of next year, an announcement that helped propel Tesla’s stock value beyond $1 trillion for the first time.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Niraj Chokshi
